channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Xi Plays Long Game on US-China Trade as Trump Seeks Quick Wins
item.description: While Donald Trump hailed the outcome of trade talks in London, Xi Jinping walked away with an understated strategic gain: a negotiating process that buys China time and helps defuse the threat of more harmful tariffs and technology curbs.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping

item.title: California Senator Handcuffed Outside Noem Briefing in LA
item.description: US Senator Alex Padilla of California was forcibly removed from a press conference and handcuffed after disrupting a media briefing by Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem on the federal immigration crackdown in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Maxwell Adler, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: U.S. Sen. Alex Padilla is pushed out of the room as Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem holds a news conference regarding the recent protests in Los Angeles on Thursday, June 12, 2025. (AP Photo/Etienne Laurent)

item.title: Trump Sees Possible ‘Massive Conflict’ Between Israel, Iran
item.description: President Donald Trump said Israel “could very well” strike Iran but that he had advised against an attack while negotiations over Tehran’s nuclear program were ongoing, as the departure of US staff from the region fans concerns about a coming strike.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Mario Parker

media:content.media:description: A replica of Iran's Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant in Isfahan, Iran. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Harvard Asks Judge to Bolster Block of Foreign Student Ban
item.description: Lawyers for Harvard University urged a federal judge to ensure that the Trump administration won’t impose alternative restrictions on the school’s enrollment of foreign students after the government’s earlier efforts were blocked.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.

item.title: Trump Administration Orders 500,000 Immigrants to Leave US
item.description: Immigrants admitted to the US from a Biden-era parole program for Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela have begun receiving notices of termination urging them to depart the US.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kreighbaum

media:content.media:description: Department of Homeland Security Police officers at San Francisco International Airport (SFO) in San Francisco, California, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Flyers heading out for the Memorial Day holiday in the US are bracing for stress as record numbers of travelers place fresh strain on an outmoded and undermanned air traffic system.

item.title: Trump’s China Trade Framework Mostly a Reset to Earlier Terms
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, White House correspondent Catherine Lucey looks at what came out of the trade talks with China this week. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

item.title: House Passes Musk’s DOGE Cuts to PBS, NPR and Foreign Aid
item.description: The US House approved $9.4 billion in Elon Musk’s DOGE federal spending cuts, with Republican moderates swallowing their concerns about cutting previously approved spending for foreign aid and public broadcasting.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: The National Public Radio headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Gold Advances on Fed Rate-Cut Bets and Middle East Tensions
item.description: Gold rose after another soft inflation report bolstered bets that the Federal Reserve may need to cut interest rates later this year.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Argentina Inflation Hits Lowest Since Covid in Win for Milei
item.description: Argentina’s monthly inflation slowed to the lowest level since the height of the pandemic, scoring a major victory for President Javier Milei ahead of a crucial midterm vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: Trump Mulls Using Defense Powers to Fund Rare-Earth Projects
item.description: The Trump administration is developing a plan to use Cold War-era powers to prioritize and fund rare earth projects it deems critical to national security, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Jenny Leonard, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Bags of rare earth concentrates sit for transport at an MP Materials mine in Mountain Pass, California.

item.title: Key Senator Looks to Slow Ted Cruz Plan on Fed Interest to Banks
item.description: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Tim Scott said he opposes swift action on a proposal that would bar the Federal Reserve from paying interest on reserves to banks to help pay for Republicans’ massive tax and spending package.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina and ranking member of the Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, speaks during a hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Martin Gruenberg, the embattled head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. told lawmakers calling for his resignation that he was moving quickly to overhaul the agency's workplace culture after a probe detailed complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination at the agency.

item.title: Russian Harvard Scientist Freed on Bail After Months in Custody
item.description: A Russian scientist at Harvard University was freed on bail by a federal judge after spending four months in detention for failing to declare biological material she brought into the US for research.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Harvard University researcher Kseniia Petrova, 30, smiles after being released on bail from federal custody at the John Joseph Moakley United States Courthouse on Thursday, June 12, 2025, in Boston. (AP Photo/Leah Willingham)

item.title: IMF Sees Unwinding of Global Trade Surge Ahead of Trump Tariffs
item.description: The International Monetary Fund is seeing signs that the rise in trade and activity to front-run US President Donald Trump’s tariffs is beginning to unwind as the global economy still faces heightened uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Loaded container ships at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. The UK doesn’t plan to use a get-out clause to override her fiscal rules, even as the US tariff war roiled global markets, forcing down the pound and UK gilts.

item.title: Millions of Acres of Public Land Sales Slated for Tax Bill
item.description: The sale of millions of acres of federal land would provide billions of dollars to help pay for President Donald Trump’s massive package of tax cuts and spending in the Senate’s version of the bill released Wednesday night.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: ARCTIC NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, ALASKA - JULY 1: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which is about the size of South Carolina, in Alaska on July 1, 2024. The fate of the refuge, its wildlife, and the oil reserves within it have been fought over for half-a-century. (Photo by Carolyn Van Houten/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Wants to Make It More Expensive to Sue Over His Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump and his allies are pursuing an alternative strategy to defend against mounting court orders blocking his policies: Raise the financial stakes for those suing the administration.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump signs an executive order in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Trump on Friday signed orders meant to accelerate the construction of nuclear power plants, including small, untested designs that offer the promise of rapid deployment but have yet to be built in the US.

item.title: US Says Export Controls to Keep Huawei AI Output Limited in 2025
item.description: A senior Trump administration official said that Huawei Technologies Co.’s ability to produce AI semiconductors will be very limited this year, responding to US lawmakers’ concerns that China is gaining ground in production of advanced semiconductors.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: Shoppers line up outside a Huawei store in Beijing.

item.title: Canadian Support for Counter-Tariffs Dips as Trump Trade War Persists
item.description: Canadians continue to support retaliating against US President Donald Trump’s wave of tariffs, but their fervor has waned as the trade war wears on.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, right, and Dominic LeBlanc, Canada's minister responsible for Canada-US trade, during a news conference on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, June 6, 2025. Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.

item.title: Trump DOJ Sues NY Over Law Blocking ICE Courthouse Arrests
item.description: The Trump Administration sued New York over a law that restricts federal immigration authorities from making arrests at state courthouses, ratcheting up tensions over enforcement actions against undocumented immigrants that have sparked protests across the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Strohm

media:content.media:description: NYPD officers outside the New York State Supreme Court Building in New York.

item.title: For Trump, Resolving US-China Trade Fight Comes at a Cost
item.description: President Donald Trump is hailing the latest trade framework with China as a game-changing breakthrough. Yet the deal he touted Wednesday represents little more than a reset back to earlier terms — and even that came at a cost.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a bill signing ceremony in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 12, 2025. Trump is set to sign three congressional resolutions on Thursday that would bar California’s plan to end the sale of gasoline-only vehicles by 2035, Reuters reports, citing a White House official it did not identify.

item.title: Italy Picks NATO Envoy as US Ambassador to Manage Trump Ties
item.description: Italy selected its envoy to NATO to take over as US ambassador, seeking to maintain friendly ties with Washington as President Donald Trump upends global trade.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Giorgia Meloni, Italy's prime minister, during a meeting in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. During her visit, Meloni plans to propose a reciprocal elimination of most industrial tariffs between the United States and the EU, in effect creating a free-trade zone.

item.title: Telefonica Looking to Boost Defense Investments, Murtra Says
item.description: Telefonica SA said it wants to ramp up investments in defense as military budgets swell across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Telefonica in Madrid, Spain.

item.title: Spain’s Sanchez Vows to Finish Term After Party Graft Report
item.description: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez dismissed calls for an early election and vowed to clean up his party after a top aide quit over graft allegations.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: Pedro Sanchez during a news conference in Madrid on June 12.

item.title: Data Centers Pose Threat to Electric Grids, US Regulator Says
item.description: Big data centers connecting to power grids is now one of the greatest near-term risks to reliability, according to a rare warning by the US agency charged with overseeing the sector.
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik

media:content.media:description: Electrical transmission towers during a heatwave in Vallejo, California, US, on Sunday, Sept. 4, 2022. Blisteringly hot temperatures and a rash of wildfires are posing a twin threat to California's power grid as a heat wave smothering the region peaks in the days ahead.

item.title: Trump Vows to Shield Farmers From Deportations That Are Depleting Workforce
item.description: President Donald Trump conceded that his immigration crackdown was hurting US businesses and said policy changes covering farmworkers and the hotel industry will be made to address worker shortages.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: US ICE agents detain a suspect during a multi-agency targeted enforcement operation in Lyons, Illinois, on Jan. 26.

item.title: East Africa Plans Spending Boost to Offset Global Risk, Aid Cuts
item.description: East African finance chiefs increased planned spending to a record to sustain economic growth and mitigate the effects of geopolitical risks and cuts in foreign aid.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the financial district in Nairobi, Kenya, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Kenyan annual inflation remained below the 5% midpoint of the central bank’s target range for a 12th straight month strengthening the case for another interest-rate cut.

item.title: Bipartisan House Bill Aims to Lift Assad-Era Sanctions on Syria
item.description: A group of six bipartisan lawmakers plan to introduce a bill that would repeal sanctions on Syria, giving a boost to White House efforts to lift restrictions on the country after the fall of President Bashar Al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle

media:content.media:description: Buildings and traffic in the city center in Damascus, Syria, on Sunday, Jan. 19, 2025. Key European Union member states want to suspend some sanctions on Syria to help ensure a peaceful transition of power after the fall of ex-President Bashar Al-Assad and enable displaced people to return home.

item.title: Gaza Aid Foundation Says Eight Workers Killed by Hamas
item.description: Eight Palestinian aid workers were killed and several injured when a bus they were traveling in was attacked by Hamas militants in central Gaza, a foundation backed by the US and Israel said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry bags containing food and humanitarian aid packages delivered by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, a U.S.-backed organization, in Rafah, southern Gaza Strip, Wednesday, June 11, 2025. (AP Photo/Abdel Kareem Hana) Photographer: Abdel Kareem Hana/AP

item.title: California Asks Judge to Limit ‘Unchecked’ Use of US Troops
item.description: California said the Trump administration’s deployment of the National Guard and US Marines to respond to protests in Los Angeles was illegal and cannot continue “unchecked.”
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, California, US, on Sunday, June 8, 2025. The deployment of National Guard troops by President Donald Trump over the weekend, despite the objections of state and city officials, led to growing friction between local leaders and the administration.

item.title: What Powers Do US States Have to Resist Trump?
item.description: Republicans have long cast themselves as the defenders of state power and opponents of a strong central government — but don’t always act that way when it’s a Republican president trying to bend states to his will. Now, with Donald Trump testing the limits of presidential reach, Democratic governors such as California’s Gavin Newsom are the ones asserting states’ authority.
item.dc:creator: Anna Edgerton

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, California, US, on Sunday, June 8, 2025. The deployment of National Guard troops by President Donald Trump over the weekend, despite the objections of state and city officials, led to growing friction between local leaders and the administration. Photographer: Kyle Grillot/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says He Offered Assistance to India After Boeing Crash
item.description: US President Donald Trump expressed his condolences after the deadly crash of a Boeing Co. 787 Dreamliner operated by Air India that left hundreds dead, saying he had offered “pointers” on possible causes as well as an offer of assistance to Indian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Mario Parker, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: The crash site of Air India Ltd. Flight 171 in Ahmedabad, India, on June 12.
